The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After these cemeteries are full, only family plots, reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19-22, offers an augmented reality app feature allowing visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews from festival items. The app also enables global interaction with the festival, providing updates, ticket purchasing, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere.

An Irish-bred 10-year-old horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, suffering from severe pulmonary hemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause, and while post-race ataxia had been observed in the horse before, it had never collapsed or shown such symptoms. Many Clouds had previously won prestigious races, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

A 15-year-old girl was raped by a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer. The defendant, now 34 and known as Davina, denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely to a male prison in Winchester, citing concerns about her risk to herself and potential non-attendance. The court heard that Ayrton raped the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage, and the victim had consumed only a small amount of alcohol.
Serbs lost to Brazilians in Rio, Djokovic knocked out by Argentine at Wimbledon, 12-time Grand Slam winner won 30th Masters title in Toronto before Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in a Saturday event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, using only chainsaws to carve animals and people from logs. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend the Claymore Trophy.

Wales fly-half Dan Evans is close to returning from a serious foot injury, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations in February. He has renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, remaining committed to playing for his region and country.

Border agents intercepted two men near the US border in Washington, attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man fired a weapon and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. Nathan Hall was later apprehended, and his backpack contained a fake driver's license. Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs. The suspects face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service counseled over 4,500 children in the past year, up from about 2,400 in 2011-12, with many as young as seven reporting online abuse. Online trolls cause significant misery and humiliation, and the charity warns that cyber-bullying can follow children home, worsening over time. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, urges adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, emphasizing that bullying does not stop on its own and often escalates. The report is released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which aims to combat the problem with support from parents, schools, and organizations.

The move to postpone a vote on authorising new homes in Israeli settlements in Jerusalem follows a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office, ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The postponement is to avoid straining relations with the US, given the recent tensions over a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlement construction and a US decision not to veto the resolution. The resolution, which passed on Friday, stated that settlement establishment has no legal validity and obstructs a two-state solution. Israel rejected the resolution, leading Netanyahu to summon US and Security Council ambassadors, recall Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancel a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. Kerry is expected to discuss the conflict and address critiques of the Obama administration during his speech.

The passage discusses Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday celebrations, including tributes, a picture of the royal family for stamps, and events such as a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail office, a ceremony to open a new bandstand, and a birthday walk and beacon lighting. It also mentions Prince William's reflection on the Queen's role as a guiding example of a good monarch and his commitment to royal duty.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew giving the Premier League side control before halftime. Cheltenham made seven changes following recent top-flight losses, but failed to sufficiently test West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, failed to spot a motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. McNicholl's family accepted the crash was a momentary lapse and found no value in Werner being sent to jail.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British fighter from Southall, London, is facing up to life imprisonment for his role in Syria's conflict. He left the UK in January, joined the extremist group Rayat al Tawheed, and posted videos and pictures of his activities, including a video where a fellow fighter recovered from a gunshot wound. Khawaja was involved in propaganda efforts, including appeals for donations and "through the keyhole" tours of fighters' quarters. After returning to the UK in June, he attempted to fake his own death and re-enter the country, leading to his arrest. He is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from conflict.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth in the table. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.

Bottles of detergent 'Vanish' have washed up on Poldhu Cove in Cornwall, likely from a container lost overboard during stormy weather. National Trust volunteers are clearing them away due to potential wildlife risk. Other nearby coves have also been affected. Conservationists are concerned about the impact on marine life.
Incident on A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at 14:00, multiple minor injuries, road closure and diversions via A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, police inquiries ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite signed a new contract with Bolton following their promotion to the Championship, joining other players like David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in doing so.

Liberal Democrats and Labour previously collaborated to defeat government amendments on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but their cooperation ended when MPs rejected the amendments. The Liberal Democrats insisted on the amendments while Labour deferred to the Commons, leading to accusations of false hope and grandstanding by the Lib Dems and criticism of Labour for aligning with the government on Brexit. Despite past joint efforts on various issues, tensions remain between the two parties.

The passage discusses the low priority of defense in the upcoming UK election, with defense spending and military issues receiving minimal attention from political parties. Defense is seen as a low concern for voters, overshadowed by the economy, healthcare, and immigration. The UK's military has been reduced in size, and the country has fallen in global defense spending rankings. Despite calls for increased defense spending, the UK is unlikely to meet the NATO target of 2% of GDP. The Ministry of Defence faces budget cuts, and there is uncertainty about the future of the Trident nuclear deterrent. The passage highlights the challenges of maintaining a capable military with limited resources and the potential for further cuts, which could impact the UK's global military presence and credibility.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar from Santos in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club's total outlay, including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and a recent tax payment, amounts to £106.8m. The club denies any tax-related wrongdoing and has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56. Sandro Rosell, the former president, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds and is under investigation.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father, died in a motorway crash caused by Albert Newman, who was driving the wrong way in a Mazda Premacy. The incident highlights concerns about the driving abilities of older drivers, prompting calls for regular driving tests and medical examinations for those over 70.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, leading to debilitating side effects for some women. An independent review by Professor Alison Britton of Glasgow Caledonian University will examine the process and conclusions of the report, which recommended patients be offered a range of treatments and mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government cannot implement one as it is the responsibility of the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to achieve consensus among panel members, and some panelists, including Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned over the publication of the report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone mesh or tape implants, with more than 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan expressed excitement and noted that Muir's race, though a mixed 3K race, was a genuine competition. British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would undergo ratification and is expected to be confirmed. McColgan praised Muir's potential, suggesting she could run a 5K under 14.30 minutes, and noted that Muir's race was reminiscent of her own record-breaking performance 25 years ago.

Jung won gold aboard Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to an infection. France's Nicolas took silver, American Dutton won bronze, and GB's Fox-Pitt finished 12th despite a recent coma. Fox-Pitt, 47, competed 10 months after his coma, leading after dressage but finishing 21st due to time penalties in cross-country. Ireland's Evans finished ninth.
Murray won a tense five-set match against Fognini to reach the fourth round, where he will face Benoit Paire. Konta also advanced to the second week with a win over Sakkari.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. The bar was ordered closed for three months due to alcohol being served late. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, had a poor record and was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, the Ulster Unionist Party leader, emphasized that "partnership works" over "domination" in his party's manifesto launch speech. He urged voters to support the party and any candidate they believe will act in the best interest of their community, constituency, and country. The election is seen as a referendum on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled, with Nesbitt criticizing the ongoing controversy over his remarks about potentially transferring to the SDLP. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' includes proposals for addressing waiting lists, increasing the PSNI to 7,500, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is disadvantaged by Brexit.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland assembly for approval, aiming to bring the jurisdiction in line with England and Wales. The motion, known as 'Turing's Law', will allow posthumous pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses and enable living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons. The minister secured executive agreement to pass a legislative consent motion to implement these provisions, aiming for equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales.

Laura Muir set a new Scottish record in the 1500m, finishing second behind Kenyan runner Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60. This achievement places her second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record, expressed her satisfaction with the accomplishment and aims to secure a spot for Great Britain in the Rio Olympics through the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26.
The passage mentions pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as the "most excellent" for water quality.

The Russian state is likely the sponsor of the plot to poison Alexander Litvinenko, who died in 2006 after drinking tea containing polonium-210 during a meeting with suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. The suspects deny wrongdoing, but evidence suggests the Russian state was involved in his murder. The inquiry is adjourned, and the suspects remain in Russia.

Steve Smith has been appointed as Australia's captain for all limited-overs formats following Michael Clarke's retirement after a heavy Ashes defeat. David Warner will serve as Smith's vice-captain, despite past disciplinary issues, and is seen as a mature senior figure. Smith, 26, has previously captained the team in Tests while Clarke was injured. The new leadership duo will lead Australia in upcoming limited-overs matches starting in August.

Farron stated he is passionate about LGBT-plus rights, supports equal marriage, and aims to extend marital rights to transgender people. He voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about protecting individual liberties, though he did not specify the exact concerns.

Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical company, is set to use the former Sanofi manufacturing site in Fawdon for its production, potentially rehiring many ex-Sanofi staff. The move is expected to create numerous jobs and positively impact the local economy, reinforcing Newcastle's status as a hub for the science and healthcare sectors.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the opposition SNP group leader, views these departures as signs of the council's struggle to retain senior staff, anticipating more exits in the future. Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving. Monaghan is the head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland is the head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked a hospital in Kabul, detonating explosives at the gate and opening fire on staff and patients. Commandos killed all four attackers after several hours of fighting. The Islamic State (IS) group claimed responsibility, while the Taliban denied involvement. Over 50 people were wounded. The attack marks a shift in IS tactics, as they have previously targeted civilian gatherings and government buildings but not directly engaged security forces in the capital. This suggests they may have gained resources and training, potentially leading to more attacks in the future.

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems. Martin told MCN that he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he has not given up on racing or road racing but has no plans to do any road racing on Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin stated that the TT was a disaster and that the bike is not competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts declared in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. This outcome reflects a significant decline for the PDP, which lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, one of the regions affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP retained only eight governorships, primarily in the south-east. The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the party failing to secure a national vote spread outside the south-east and Niger Delta. Despite the APC's historic gains, it did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a factor that could impact President-elect Buhari's ability to manage militant threats to oil production. The elections, while marred by some violence, were more peaceful than previous years, suggesting progress in Nigeria's democracy.

The passage discusses allegations made by the environmental lobby group Mighty against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses both companies of sourcing palm oil from rogue traders and small-scale farmers engaging in slash-and-burn practices, contributing to haze caused by fires in Indonesia. Both Olam and Temasek deny the allegations, with Olam stating it has a strict sourcing policy and that producers not meeting its standards are removed from its supply chain. The report suggests that Temasek, as a majority stakeholder in Olam, may be indirectly financing practices that affect Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The palm oil industry is highlighted as having a troubled reputation due to labor practices, deforestation, and environmental concerns, with NGOs and executives often at odds over regulation and enforcement. The report also mentions concerns about Olam's activities in Gabon, where it is accused of clearing rainforests for palm oil plantations.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters after a new law permitted dogs to dine outdoors at restaurants.
Fernando Forestieri (knee) is a doubt, David Nugent (groin) could return, and Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall.

The ban on YouTube in Pakistan has been lifted as Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed all internet service providers to open access to YouTube. YouTube stated that content requests from the government would not be automatically granted, citing its community guidelines. Activists, however, are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government.

The passage discusses the upcoming FIFA presidential election in 18 days, involving five candidates including Swiss-Italian Domenico Scala and Gianni Infantino. Scala, who heads FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is under pressure to withdraw due to a potential conflict of interest, as he shares nationality with one of the candidates. The Liberian FA's LFA boss Musa Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The text also mentions the history of Scala and Claudio Sulser stepping down from the committee in 2015 for similar reasons, and the ongoing debate over whether nationality alone constitutes a conflict of interest.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed on Monday at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday. A forensic search was conducted, and evidence suggests a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and ignition. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

Tunisia and Morocco faced bans from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints and a Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned these bans. Morocco's ban was related to a 2015 incident where they were replaced as hosts for the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, and a fine was imposed on their federation. Tunisia's issue arose from a controversial penalty awarded against them during a quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, leading to a dispute with Caf that was resolved after a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Both teams are now set to participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.

Chelsea won the match 3-1 at Etihad Stadium, with City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, and Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's actions. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charge.

A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd is focusing on family doctors treating patients with undiagnosed cancer, aiming to improve cancer detection rates in Wales. Doctors in Cwm Taf have noted an increase in cancer diagnosis services in Denmark, leading to better cancer detection rates. The concern is that patients in Wales with cancer may go undiagnosed for a long time due to the lack of clear symptoms, making early diagnosis difficult. Family doctors in Cwm Cynon are considering patients for referral to diagnostic centers at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant within a week. The plan is to screen all 40 patients and provide different tests on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with symptoms considered "concerning" are diagnosed in the Cwm Taf area. Family doctors aim to reach the majority of patients with less obvious cancer symptoms. A similar clinic will be established in Castell-nedd Port Talbot as part of another pilot project by the Health Protection Agency of Abertawe Bro Morgannwg. The initiative aims to improve both the speed of diagnosis and the overall process. Dr Gareth Davies, Cancer Wales Network Lead, believes the scheme will not only speed up the process but also improve patient outcomes by allowing quicker referral to clinics.

England won the fourth Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They scored 589-8 and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 and 71 in the second innings, as well as his four catches and one wicket. England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it "an extraordinary player." Pakistan were bowled out for 234, with their spirit broken by England's disciplined batting and bowling. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott praised England's quality and discipline. England is expected to enjoy the win but the series remains tight, according to Vaughan. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, citing poor confidence and shot selection.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with Rob Howley as interim coach and forwards coach McBryde taking on head coach duties for the third time, following his experience leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour, with discussions progressing to confirm the full management team. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit Welsh rugby.

Hull City secured their first league win since August 20, ending a six-game losing streak, while Southampton remains in the relegation zone. The match was marred by injuries to Hull's strikers, but Snodgrass's goals in the 61st and 67th minutes, along with a crucial goalline clearance by Clucas in added time, turned the tide in Hull's favor.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash on the B1191 near Thornton, Woodhall Spa at 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, citing the need to end turmoil ahead of June elections. The move was criticized by the opposition and EU officials, who argued it was illegal and jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership prospects. The crisis began in 2015 when recordings allegedly showed ministers plotting vote-rigging and murder cover-ups, with the opposition leader, Zaev, accusing the government of widespread corruption and wiretapping. The government denies these allegations.

Swansea City appoints Paul Williams as interim manager for the match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club aims to appoint a new permanent manager soon, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis, a former player, believes the team has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent management changes and a dilution of the "Swansea Way." Despite losing key players, Curtis remains confident in the squad's ability to stay up, emphasizing the club's significant journey from near bankruptcy to Premier League promotion.

Leyton Orient secured a crucial victory over Dagenham and Redbridge, keeping their slim play-off hopes alive after being held to a 2-0 lead. The win, which came four days after Kevin Nolan was removed as manager, leaves Orient two points behind the play-off spots. The match was significant as it marked the return of Dagenham to the National League under former League One club manager John Still, who previously led the team to promotion. Despite the win, Orient's season has been marred by defensive struggles and a poor goal difference, while Dagenham's manager highlighted the team's lack of organization and discipline as key factors in their recent challenges.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. The former Reds captain, who won multiple major titles with Liverpool, expressed interest in becoming a manager in the future. Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp described the appointment as "wonderful news" and believes Gerrard's playing experience combined with his eagerness to learn will lead to a bright future in football. Gerrard, who retired in November after a 19-year career, had previously been linked with the manager's job at League One side MK Dons but decided the opportunity came too soon. He is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching licence, required for Premier League management.
McManus scored twice to lead Morton, but Alloa's Kyle McAusland and Denny Johnstone also scored, resulting in a comfortable Morton win.

Ofsted has identified three unregistered schools in Birmingham where children were taught in squalid conditions, leading to their closure and ongoing investigations. Illegal schools could face up to 51 weeks in jail. Ofsted has visited 18 unregulated schools in Muslim communities across the Midlands, with concerns about potential child abuse and radicalization. The government is consulting on stricter regulations for places teaching more than 6-8 hours weekly and plans to prosecute identified unregistered schools with the Education Secretary's consent.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. The distillery aims to create a "region of distilling excellence" using local botanicals and wild ingredients from the Teviot valley, fitting into a cowshed. The name Lilliard honors a legendary local heroine, reflecting the landscape and the strong female team behind the project.

Harry Whitlam died after being hit by a vehicle driven by Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit, on private land near Leeds in August 2013. Green, who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and hope that Harry's life would be remembered for the good times shared, emphasizing that being drunk and driving is unacceptable.

Uruguay striker Luis Suarez, 27, can now train and play in friendly matches for Barcelona after an appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) was unsuccessful. The club confirmed that Suarez will join the first team's training session on Friday and will be publicly presented as a new Barcelona player on Monday at Camp Nou. Despite the ruling, Suarez still faces the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup and is unlikely to play in competitive matches until his ban is served. However, he will be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan, South Korea, and Saudi Arabia.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the Tough Mudder race in Lithuania, overcoming strong competition from Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles including hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Participants included various combinations of men and women, carrying each other. The winners will compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond addressed concerns about job losses at the DVLA following the scrapping of car tax discs in October, assuring that while some job roles may change due to the introduction of an electronic system, any reductions will be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business.

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban's government has passed laws on asylum seekers, higher education, and NGOs, facing EU pressure to withdraw them. Hungary is housing asylum seekers in secured containers, and the higher education law could close the prestigious Central European University. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls and higher education law, with Poland vowing to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary.

The 2017 animated film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast features Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and Harry Styles as Gaston, with Josh Gad voicing LeFou. The movie will be directed by Bill Condon and released in the US on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away after a battle with cancer. Known for his distinctive writing style and fearless journalism, Gill was described by colleagues as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. His final column addressed his diagnosis, and tributes from fellow writers and editors highlighted his significant contributions to journalism and his unique voice. Despite his controversial writing style, which often sparked debate, Gill's impact on the industry was profound.

Rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was attacked in Ulan Bator while performing, allegedly hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy investigated but called local reports "distorted," noting inaccuracies in the date, number of participants, and circumstances. Sukhbaatar's father emphasized that the swastika, worn by his son on stage, is a traditional Mongolian symbol of eternity, not a hate symbol. The attacker, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been identified, and the case remains under investigation.
Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a protest against airport expansion plans, charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area, to appear in court on 19 August.

Nick Selman scored a mature 101 off 144 balls, his second first-class century, while seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles consistently dismissed wickets, leading to a balanced day for Gloucestershire as Glamorgan secured a consolation bonus point with Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee about a planned murder of police officers. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes claimed he intended to make a false report to the police, leading them to the Dee Estuary, where he would shoot them. The threats were made while he was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded Hughes in custody pending sentence, noting his previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009.

Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by a three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker, who dismissed Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan scored 68 but was the last to fall, leaving Yorkshire all out for 236. Yorkshire, aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 after losing in the T20 Blast semi-finals, lost by 27 runs.
A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST due to a pump unable to cope with incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Hellen Muir, a middle distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine studies, which have exams in May. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir expressed her disappointment at missing the Commonwealths but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. She remains optimistic about her future, potentially targeting the World Indoor Championships in March.

Liverpool is far from a title contender this season, struggling with a weaker attack, defensive issues, and a lack of intensity. Manager Brendan Rodgers faces challenges in rebuilding the team, particularly in the striker position, and must improve to secure a top-four finish. Steven Gerrard's future remains uncertain despite his continued importance to the team, as he faces a mental and physical battle to maintain his role.

A £45m facility in Kilmarnock will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. The campus will be named after William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, who became an English teacher and later a full-time writer, earning the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" through works like the Laidlaw trilogy and Docherty.

An area near a swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated and residents advised to stay indoors due to a sea mine spotted on Monday, believed to be British from the 1940s or 1950s. The mine remains in an exclusion zone, affecting three streets and a half-mile sea area, with ferry services disrupted. Authorities deemed the evacuation precautionary and are moving the mine to a safer location before further action.

The passage discusses the decision to cut funding for several sports, including badminton, cycling, and weightlifting, as part of the UK's investment in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games. Badminton, which had previously won a bronze medal in Rio, saw its funding removed, causing significant concern for its players and officials. Cycling's funding was reduced to £25.98m from £29.98m, while weightlifting's funding was cut by £1.5m to £25m. The decision to cut funding was made despite Britain's strong performance at the Rio 2016 Games, with 67 Olympic medals and 147 Paralympic medals. UK Sport has set targets for Team GB to win 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo, emphasizing the need to maintain and enhance medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels will be demolished to make way for a new six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks at East Cliff in Bournemouth. Despite objections from English Heritage and some residents concerned about the loss of historic character, councillors voted in favor of the development, citing its potential to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents in the town.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was off-duty and out on a night out in Brecon when he was attacked and beaten by Jake Vallely. Vallely, who had been drinking heavily, punched and dragged Boyd from a bar before fleeing. Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Boyd's body was found unconscious in the town early on 8 May, and Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. The community and Boyd's family mourned his loss, describing him as loving, caring, and full of life.

Andrew Travers resigned from his position as chief executive of Barnet Council following an error that led to all 155 polling stations being closed on election day due to voters being turned away because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to review the situation, which will conclude by the end of May and present findings publicly to the General Functions Committee. The investigation will assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum in June. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over leadership during the investigation.
Gateshead won 2-1 against Wrexham, with goals scored by Josh Gillies and Ryan Bowman. The match saw strong performances from both teams, with Gateshead improving in the second half.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, with Norway ranked highest and Afghanistan and Mozambique ranked lowest.

The OneWeb project aims to create a constellation of at least 600, and potentially over 2,000, satellites to provide global broadband internet access, including to schools. This ambitious endeavor requires a significant shift in satellite manufacturing, focusing on high volume and low cost, with new assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and Florida, USA, designed to produce satellites at a much lower cost and faster rate than traditional methods. The project involves a massive rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles planned to launch clusters of satellites into orbit. OneWeb, based in the UK's Channel Islands, is seeking regulatory approval and has raised $1.7 billion in equity, with ongoing discussions for additional financing. The company is committed to debris mitigation, aiming to de-orbit satellites within two years and incorporating hardware to facilitate the retrieval of malfunctioning spacecraft.

The Scottish government argues that UK government cuts since 2010, along with the recent spending review, have reduced its discretionary budget by 12.5% in real terms by 2019-20. Mr Swinney claims the chancellor has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year until 2020, with over £1bn still to come. The Scottish government is determined to defend key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. The UK government's Scotland Office responds by stating that Scottish ministers will have £390m more spending available next year, with the block grant nearly £30bn, presenting it as a better deal for Scotland than the constitutional alternative.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities, particularly those requiring specialized facilities for changing, when accessing public spaces. It highlights the need for Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced facilities for such individuals, and the current lack of compulsory installation in public buildings. The passage includes personal stories of families affected by the lack of accessible facilities and the efforts of campaigners to make these toilets compulsory in larger public buildings.

Italian consumers' organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging that the company forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's claims it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and has been successful in creating the best opportunities for them and customers. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate the charges. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to longer-than-average contracts and that they lease premises at above-market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's generated $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

Joshua Martin, a 13-year-old from Donaghadee, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, leading to the discovery and removal of a large primary cancer and five smaller growths. The diagnosis prompted a social media campaign initiated by Bangor Elim Church, where his father serves, using the hashtag #prayforjosh. The campaign, which began on Facebook and Instagram, has garnered global support, with the church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, expressing amazement at the widespread response. The hashtag's popularity led to a massive billboard appearing in Holywood and significant support on Twitter from Josh's classmates. The community's kindness has resulted in a global outpouring of support for Joshua as he recovers from his illness.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in the UK, with Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies condemning the decision, citing its long history and significance. The closure is part of a broader reorganization of military buildings and regiments in the UK, which includes the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, and the closure of Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, defended the restructuring but warned of the potential impact on the livelihoods of those affected.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting concerns about the risk of marginalization in broader Brexit negotiations and the complex issue of shared fish stocks with EU states. It notes that while Brexit could offer opportunities for the industry to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish exporter, it may also require trade-offs, such as granting EU-registered boats access to UK waters in exchange for continued market access. The report suggests retaining many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy and maintaining scientific advice in setting quotas, but warns of the possibility of four different fisheries management regimes in the UK if the CFP framework is abandoned. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the future prospects for British fishing post-Brexit.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed leaks about the NSA's extensive surveillance activities, which include access to chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The US government requested millions of Verizon phone records, and the NSA reportedly gained "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple. While the NSA claims these operations secure Americans, experts question the extent of the surveillance. Data protection laws vary by country, and user data is often stored outside the user's country, raising concerns about privacy and international cooperation. Other governments, including the UK, have not confirmed involvement in Prism, and the EU Justice Commission expressed concern over the program's impact on EU citizens. Privacy advocates warn that widespread surveillance undermines individual privacy.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to conduct AI research free from financial constraints to benefit humanity, while acknowledging potential risks and ensuring AI remains an extension of human will and widely distributed.

L/Bdr Parkinson, seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch in Doncaster, receiving thousands of Facebook friend requests due to his public status. Despite Facebook's limit of 5,000 friends per personal page, his mother Diane noted the overwhelming support and interest, with his page receiving 19,000 hits on an update and numerous requests to visit places with the torch.

In 2011, the US poverty rate was 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, with a flat trend after three years of increases. The real median household income dropped by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%, marking the first annual rise since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, signed a new deal with Lancashire in 2013, tying him to the club until 2019. He is known for scoring England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and his positive impact on the team, noting his experience benefits the squad. Buttler, who plays in the Indian Premier League for Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders having until 23 January to register interest. No preservation proposals have been submitted, and final decisions are expected in the spring. The government aims to award at least one to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, prefers saving one for a reef and diving attraction, emphasizing the value of a noble second life for the ships. Originally designed for anti-submarine warfare, the Type 22 frigates evolved into powerful surface combatants with advanced weapons and communication systems.

Racial and political tensions, primarily between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, have caused instability and international isolation since 1987. Key events include a 1987 coup, a 2000 coup led by a businessman, and a 2006 military takeover. These events have severely impacted the economy, particularly tourism, and strained diplomatic relations, leading to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with a growing indigenous majority due to migration. The economy, reliant on sugar and tourism, remains diverse but faces persistent trade and budget deficits, resulting in significant aid dependency.

Syria is struggling to meet its deadline for destroying chemical weapons, with shipments intercepted by terrorist groups. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad defended the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, accusing the US of supporting terrorism. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have seized control of Aleppo's central prison, while international organizations claim the prison is now under rebel control. The US expressed concern over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons stockpile, which has only seen about 4% of the declared 1,300 tonnes leave the country. Russia has set a new deadline for the transfer of chemical weapons to the coast by March 1, and the destruction process has been slowed by security concerns.

The 46th Booker Prize shortlist includes six English-language authors from various nationalities, with Mukherjee's The Lives of Others, Ali Smith's How To Be Both, Joshua Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, Karen Joy Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves, Richard Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North, and Howard Jacobson's J. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night.

The Supreme Court is reviewing an appeal against a ruling that lifted a ban on naming a celebrity in the media in England and Wales. The celebrity, who has young children and a public spouse, is appealing against a decision that previously prevented his identity from being disclosed due to alleged extra-marital activities. The Sun on Sunday sought to publish an account of these activities, but the ban was initially upheld by appeal court judges. The Supreme Court will decide whether to grant the appeal and potentially allow or dismiss the case, with an interim injunction remaining in place until the hearing's conclusion.

Fosse Park, purchased for £345.5m in August, is undergoing improvements to address parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners aim to enhance the park's quality and facilities, viewing it as a strategic investment to improve its appeal as a gateway into the city.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia after a "gay moment" was identified, leading Disney to request a review of its content by the Malaysian Censorship Board. The board approved the film with a minor edit concerning the gay moment, allowing its screening despite the country's laws against homosexual activity. A new release date has not been announced, and local cinema chains have offered refunds to advance ticket buyers. The controversy drew criticism from netizens who questioned the selective enforcement of moral standards in Malaysia.

Landlords in Southampton who rent out properties to more than three unrelated people are required to obtain a licence for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO), despite potential fines of up to £20,000. The council estimates there are around 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, with tenants often citing fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties as concerns. Mandatory licensing for HMOs applies to houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people, affecting properties in various districts of Southampton. While most landlords have cooperated with the licensing process, a small number have resisted, resulting in prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to avoid a second election, with water charges being a major obstacle. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being proposed, with Fianna Fáil seeking immediate removal of charges and Fine Gael favoring a role for them. Post-election, the parties had no majority, with Fine Gael at 50, Fianna Fáil at 44, Sinn Féin at 23, and the Labour Party at 7.

The Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on one of its car decks, prompting a rapid evacuation to lifeboats. The ship, approximately 27km from Mallorca, was rescued by a ferry, with passengers and crew taken on board. At least three people, including one seriously injured, were hospitalized via helicopter. The cause of the fire remains unclear. The ship may sink, and psychologists are being prepared to provide counseling at the port in Palma de Mallorca upon the passengers' arrival.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs identified individuals, including students, who claimed to have voted twice, a criminal offense. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June 8 election, with 68.7% voting on the day, the highest turnout since 1997. Duplicate applications surged after the snap poll announcement, with 2.9 million applications received over six weeks. Despite efforts to prevent duplicates, the lack of direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service led to significant administration and financial burdens, with estimates of 30% to 70% duplicate applications. The watchdog called for clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, and for voters registered in two constituencies to choose one in advance. Labour warned against making voter registration more difficult for young people.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and star University of Nebraska athlete, died by suicide on Wednesday. He played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers before facing legal issues, including convictions for assault and domestic violence. After his NFL career, Phillips was imprisoned for over 30 years. He was accused of killing his former cellmate and was found to have enough evidence to try him for the death of Damion Soward, 37.

Private Derby XXX, a ram mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal at a Chester event marking eight years of the regiment. Awarded the honor by Brigadier Andrew Williams, Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny. He joined the regiment in 2014, holds an army number, receives pay for rations, and vacations during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. Derby XXX has assisted with Christmas lights and met Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, with Dejan Lovren scoring in injury time. The win, which moved Liverpool closer to a Champions League spot, was marked by Liverpool's resilience and belief, overcoming an early deficit and a dominant performance from Dortmund. The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with a minute's silence for the Hillsborough disaster and a passionate display by fans. Liverpool's manager Jurgen Klopp's intense touchline presence and the team's refusal to give up were key factors in their success. The victory is seen as a significant moment for Liverpool, reinforcing Klopp's influence and the team's potential for future success.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee meeting in London discussed UK government plans for negotiating the UK's exit from the EU. UK Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, David Davis, stated that the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about negotiations and hold monthly meetings to share analysis and information. Scottish Secretary David Russell emphasized the need for greater transparency from the UK government regarding its plans, particularly on whether the UK intends to remain in the single market or customs union. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court regarding the High Court judgment on triggering Article 50.

The passage describes 13 cloned sheep, including four that are identical twins to Dolly, the first cloned mammal. These sheep are being closely monitored and studied at the University of Nottingham to assess their health and aging process. Researchers are particularly interested in whether cloning affects aging, as indicated by potential premature development of diseases like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The study involves regular examinations, X-rays, and fMRI scans to compare the health of the cloned sheep with a control group. Preliminary results suggest that the cloned sheep are in good health as they approach their ninth and tenth birthdays.

Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, bringing a fifth Musidora win for trainer John Gosden and jockey Julian Dettori. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may not enter him in the Derby trial. Shutter Speed, who won comfortably in soft conditions, will go to France's Oaks next, with Gosden relying on stablemates Enable and Coronet in the Epsom Oaks.

The pound initially fell against the dollar and euro, then recovered before falling again, with the volatility index reaching crisis-era levels. The pound is down 0.2% against the dollar and 0.6% against the euro, reflecting uncertainty amid data showing a decreasing chance of a Remain vote and global economic worries. Two recent polls suggest the Leave campaign is ahead, and the implied probability of a Remain vote has dropped to 68.5%. Analysts expect further volatility as the referendum approaches, with hedge funds short-selling sterling. The FTSE 100 ended down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group leading the decline, while Asian markets also fell due to concerns over the economic impact of leaving the EU.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place away from the play-offs. They lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games, while Braintree's losing streak continued to three games. Despite the challenges, manager Cowley remains positive, emphasizing the team's remarkable journey and their determination to embrace and enjoy the tough challenge ahead.

The passage discusses a proposed change in Northern Ireland where local councils will take over the responsibility of making planning decisions, shifting from the current system where the Planning Service under the environment department makes final decisions. This move aims to democratize the planning system, allowing councils to develop their own community and development plans. However, concerns are raised about whether local politicians possess the necessary skills for urban regeneration and planning, and about the potential for unfair and opaque handling of planning matters, reminiscent of past discrimination in housing allocation. Environmental groups warn that transparency and strict enforcement of a code of conduct are crucial to prevent favoritism and maintain public trust. There is also debate over the impact of donation limits on political parties and the potential deterrence of donors.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times by an air gun, resulting in injuries to her shoulder and leg, which required amputation. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, expressed distress over the incident and the potential danger to children in the area. The Scottish SPCA emphasized the need for urgent licensing of air guns to prevent such incidents, highlighting that a majority of respondents to a previous government consultation opposed the proposed licensing plan.

Benteke becomes Liverpool's second most expensive signing on a long-term contract, following the club's sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m. The 24-year-old Belgian international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. Liverpool, aiming to improve their goal-scoring after a poor season last year, signed Benteke to bolster their attack alongside Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Former Villa and Liverpool manager Paul Lambert and striker John Aldridge express confidence in Benteke's ability to contribute significantly to the team.

The study by Tablets for Schools, led by Barbie Clarke, examines the use of tablet computers in 671 state and independent schools. While 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for students using them. Tablet usage varies widely, with 9% of schools having one device per pupil and higher usage in academy schools. The study predicts a significant increase in tablet use in schools from 430,000 to nearly 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. Head teachers report positive impacts, such as increased motivation for disengaged students and greater family involvement. A separate study highlights the benefits of touch-screen computers for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. Tablet use is pervasive among young people, with many taking devices to bed for social media. School leaders like Simon Mason advocate for tablets, emphasizing their role in preparing students for modern life and fostering empowerment and trust.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing children's lives in the city over more than a century, from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images illustrate the evolution of childhood experiences and how special occasions were celebrated on Liverpool's streets. The oldest photograph, from 1887, shows the Rollo family at a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle. The exhibition also highlights the working lives of some children. Curator Kay Jones selected the images from the Museum of Liverpool's collections, emphasizing both the joyful and challenging aspects of childhood. The exhibition runs until September 25.
Anderson, 27, cancels Barrow contract to join National League rivals. Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, could play against former club on 18 February. Gulls aim to overcome relegation issues.

The new Bolivian law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, sets a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide, and aims to address extreme poverty while balancing local needs and international standards.

A 50-year-old woman, who is a TV star, experienced a severe heart attack after helping a woman struggling out of her car. She initially thought she had the flu but later realized her symptoms were those of a heart attack. She searched online for women's heart attack symptoms, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. She did not call emergency services but warned others to recognize heart attack symptoms and call 911.

A 16-year-old boy from Harrow, identified as Che Labastide-Wellington, was stabbed and died after a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, on Saturday evening. He was stabbed in an alleyway at about 00:30 GMT and pronounced dead an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital; his condition was stable. Police believe Che was not involved in an early altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two 15- and 16-year-old boys were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old boy is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes a Danish approach to improving cancer diagnosis and treatment, which involves three main routes: fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. This system has led to better organization, reduced waiting times, and improved survival rates, with Denmark now performing better compared to other European countries.

A new service led by Powys council will issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents, following the UK government's decision to disband the OFT. Powys won the bid to deliver this service, receiving £170,000 annually. Complaints will still be directed to local authority trading standards, who will prosecute if necessary, but will be referred to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is breached.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce to address shortages, with the Nuffield Trust identifying opportunities for nurses and pharmacists to fill roles previously held by doctors. This approach could help manage patient care for long-term conditions but unions caution against using it as a quick fix, emphasizing the need for adequate funding and training.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place due to a crash that caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The closure, which lasted until 14:00 GMT, has led to ongoing investigations into the collision. While some services have resumed normal schedules, a full return to normal is expected in a few hours.

The passage discusses the impact of the Swansea tidal lagoon project on local fish populations, with NRW estimating that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout would die annually due to the lagoon. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they lack scientific basis and were based on hypothetical scenarios. TLP's own modeling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species being affected. The project, valued at £1.3 billion, is seen as a test bed for larger versions along the coast. The Welsh Government supports the scheme but seeks clarity on the UK government's position. NRW remains confident in its assessment, based on extensive evidence and expert analysis.

The Northern Ireland agri-food industry, which employs nearly 100,000 people, will establish a new industry-led marketing body similar to Scotland's Food and Drink. The Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) will develop the body, which will provide strategic leadership and coordination for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting the importance of agri-food in export-led economic growth, but expressed concerns about potential implications for other organizations.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to commemorate WW1, planting 40,000 native trees in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict. This four-year project, one of the trust's most ambitious, aims to create a lasting tribute where wildlife can thrive and people can reflect.

Hilary's novel "Someone Else's Skin" won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award, praised for its finely written and tightly plotted approach to domestic violence and honor crimes. Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her creation of the detective VI Warshawski, recognized for changing the portrayal of female protagonists and founding Sisters In Crime. The awards were presented at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival.

Mitch Santner, 24, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team's qualification hopes. He will return to the team after the ICC Trophy in June, aiming to make up for lost time and make an impact with his bat and ball.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 when a speeding car struck him on a dual carriageway in Kiev as he attempted to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, returned to a restaurant to retrieve a missing glove. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, noting that the evidence, though largely circumstantial, was overwhelming. Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than Pring, was suspected of involvement in his death to inherit his assets. She sold his Range Rover, emptied his bank account, and was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate. The Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it in 2011 as a murder inquiry, though it remains active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, requires experimental T-Cell Therapy in Seattle, USA, as it is unavailable in the UK. After his last transplant failed, his mother expressed her joy and gratitude for an anonymous donor who paid for his treatment, which was previously unobtainable in the UK.

The passage discusses Apple's implementation of two-step verification for iCloud accounts to prevent unauthorized access and data theft. This security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after entering their username and password. The process aims to block unauthorized access and purchases, and users can regain access using a 14-character recovery key. The update addresses vulnerabilities exploited by hackers using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which allowed attackers to download complete backups of users' data. While the new system enhances security, concerns remain about the recovery key's usability and potential theft. Experts recommend making two-factor authentication the default option across various tech companies.

Dan Groves mentioned that the "finer points" of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay, who are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, have not been disclosed. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up, has played non-league football for various clubs. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who plans to invest £10,000 a week. Paul Konchesky, a former England international, joined the club at the start of March.

Mr Ashley is under investigation for the treatment of his workers at the Derbyshire company's warehouse. He has been invited by the BIS select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, to respond by 21 March. The committee has offered alternative dates but Mr Ashley has not agreed to any. If he fails to respond, the committee may seek further action, including support from the House of Commons.

The passage discusses a report, titled "Putin. War," which was intended to detail the involvement of Russia in the conflict in eastern Ukraine. Led by Ilya Yashin, the report's authors argue that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to securing key victories for pro-Russian rebels. They present evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit to being directed by Russian generals to participate in the conflict. The report also highlights the financial compensation offered to these soldiers, estimated at 53 billion rubles. Despite the availability of these facts, the report faces challenges in publication and distribution due to opposition from publishers and the broader public's acceptance of Russia's involvement. The opposition aims to use the report to accuse President Putin of waging war for his own ends, a claim that has been largely successful in maintaining his popularity.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. He died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and are in custody.

The passage discusses the controversy over the UK government's Article 50 letter, with Carwyn Jones criticizing the lack of prior notification and the perceived disrespect shown to devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defends the government's actions, emphasizing their discussions and the stated aim to develop a negotiating framework for the whole UK. The letter mentions consulting on which powers should reside in Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, with the expectation of a significant increase in decision-making power for the devolved administrations. However, the specific powers and accompanying funding remain unclear, leading to uncertainty and debate.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, with police officers attacked while carrying out duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed shock and disapproval of the attacks on officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed for parents to ensure their children's safety.

Mr Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The company filed a court case against him, alleging he engaged in sexual harassment and made racially derogatory comments. Mr Charney's lawyer claims the statements are false and accuses the company of invading his privacy to extort him. The company argues it would be too risky to hire Mr Charney again, and a restraining order was issued to prevent him from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.
GB basketball team to play home game against Greece at Copper Box, aiming for revenge after earlier loss in Patras, Greece.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the launch of the iPhone in 2007, describing how the device was initially exclusive and how the author eventually received a prototype to use. The author reflects on the iPhone's revolutionary impact, noting that it transformed photography and enabled powerful computing capabilities on mobile devices. The passage highlights the iPhone's role in changing how people interact with technology and media, making it a key transformative technology of the 2000s. It also mentions the subsequent influence of other companies like Amazon and Google in advancing mobile technology with AI-driven innovations.

Cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have ingested a toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen being the most recent victim. Three other cats died in the past week, and another died two weeks ago. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, especially antifreeze, to prevent leaks and spills.

Greece is experiencing a surge in tourism despite the Syriza government's plans for more austerity measures, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. Greeks are largely silent about upcoming painful tax increases, pension cuts, and further privatizations, possibly due to the upcoming revelation of how much Alexis Tsipras has conceded to secure €86 billion in new credit from the eurozone and IMF. Despite his popularity, Tsipras faces criticism for failing to end fiscal austerity and for imposing monetary austerity through bank closures, which hinder lending and economic activity. The new bailout deal will only succeed if it offers genuine prospects for recovery, requiring significant debt relief from creditors.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders to play Grant Mitchell for Barbara Wright's final episodes, as her character is set to be killed off due to her cancer returning. Grant, a long-standing and iconic character in the show, will reunite with his family, including his brother Phil, for emotional scenes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked Alice Ruggles, fatally attacking her in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, described the moment police informed them of the murder and their realization that Dhillon was the perpetrator. Hills expressed guilt for initially reassuring Alice that the stalking would be harmless. The parents have since established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

The French firm EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power project in Somerset, with contracts to be signed on Friday. However, the UK government announced it would "consider carefully" before backing the project, leading EDF CEO Vincent de Rivaz to cancel a trip to Hinkley Point. Critics warn of environmental damage, escalating costs, and concerns about foreign government involvement, with one third of the cost funded by Chinese investors. The government's review has caused significant impact, potentially halting major post-Brexit investment and affecting Anglo-French relations. EDF executives were taken by surprise, and the project's future remains uncertain.

The new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse has committed adultery with, despite family lawyers' concerns that naming a third party adds conflict and complexity. The Ministry of Justice clarifies there is no obligation to name anyone, but many applicants may feel compelled to do so. Naming a third party can complicate the legal process, potentially leading to delays and additional costs, and may reflect poorly on the petitioner in the eyes of the court.

The passage discusses a conflict in Wales between promoting commercial forestry for timber and emphasizing environmental policies. While Britain is a major importer of wood, Welsh ministers are encouraging investment in woodland creation to meet timber needs. However, there is a push for more native, broadleaf species and better access for recreation, which can conflict with commercial interests. Confor warns that significant areas of commercial forest need replanting, and the Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development through initiatives like Glastir and the Woodlands for Wales strategy. Despite the market demand for timber, bureaucratic challenges and a focus on environmental aspects are seen as barriers to achieving the necessary 20,000 hectares of new woodland annually.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street. Emergency crews responded to the scene around 16:40, and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Russian Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. The convoys, which ran from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II, faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe weather, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy had planned to award the medals to survivors since 2012, but the Foreign Office initially blocked the gesture due to rules on foreign medals awarded more than five years after the event. The British Government later created the Arctic Star in 2012, and an exception was made in 2013, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the first Ushakov medals during his visit to London.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant delays and lax enforcement of community work orders, with many offenders being let off for non-attendance. In one case, an offender completed only 16 hours of work in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's recommendations, which include reducing instances of offenders being turned away for being on time and aligning work objectives with individual circumstances. The report highlights the need for better organization and enforcement of community sentences, which are intended to be a "tough" alternative to imprisonment.

The paper criticized the comedian for hypocrisy, accusing him of campaigning for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. The comedian, known for his vlogs, faced questions about his own affluent lifestyle during a campaign supporting east London residents against gentrification. He responded by calling the journalist "a snide" and walking off, and later defended his stance on change and wealth sharing, acknowledging his own past mistakes but emphasizing the ongoing issues of economic disparity and ecological disaster.

Dr Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping into a competitive race, facing criticism from the scientific community. He founded private research institutes and commercial companies to advance genomic research, achieving significant milestones such as sequencing the first complete genome of a free-living organism and announcing plans to create synthetic life. His work has been both controversial and influential, contributing to rapid advancements in genomics and inspiring further research into synthetic biology.
