Four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The survey, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, found that school meals can help encourage children to try new foods and increase dietary variety.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish forward playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. He scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata played in back-to-back Champions League finals for Real Madrid and Juventus. He scored three goals for Spain in the Euro 2016 tournament.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances in two seasons. Released in May, he has been without a team. Previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco is disposing of its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy, transferring around 4,000 employees to a new business, and will cost Tesco £150m, with part of the cost being a loan that may be paid back. Fresh & Easy, operating 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since 2007, and the remaining 50 stores will be closed. Tesco may have the option to buy a stake if the new business becomes profitable.
The individual overcame racial abuse and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, after briefly considering representing France.

The French Alps have experienced significant glacier retreat since the late 1960s/early 1970s, with the ice-covered area falling from about 375 sq km to 275 sq km by the late 2000s, representing an average loss of 26% over 40 years. The greatest losses have occurred in the southern sectors, particularly in the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs, where glaciers have almost disappeared or retreated more than three times faster than in the Mont Blanc Massif. This retreat is attributed to lower mountain elevations and differing climatic conditions in the south compared to the north, where glaciers like La Mer de Glace have shown less significant loss. The research, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, highlights ongoing efforts to monitor glacier health across the Alpine region.

Scotland's women's national football team, aiming for their first major finals in the Netherlands, face Iceland in a crucial qualifier at Falkirk Stadium, with victory likely securing their place. The Scots, unbeaten in five qualifiers, are determined to avoid another near-miss after previous play-off losses to Euro 2013 and the World Cup. Iceland, ranked just above Scotland, are unbeaten after four wins from four, and the outcome of the match and a return fixture in Reykjavik will likely determine the top spot in the group. Scotland are in pole position to qualify automatically with the best six of the eight group runners-up advancing. The team, bolstered by players from abroad including Bayern Munich's Evans and Kim Little, believes international exposure enhances their performance and competitiveness.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence advocate, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London about harassment over a two-year period. The harassment allegedly involved tweets from his Twitter account, which he denied were threatening. Campbell was released on bail and stated that the media's reporting of the incident has exaggerated the situation, focusing on tweets that are not threatening. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation of online harassment.

The People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) wants Skegness, a Lincolnshire resort, to replace its iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern, animal-friendly version. PETA suggests a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote train travel to Skegness, has become synonymous with the resort. However, PETA criticizes the Jolly Fisherman for evoking images of animal cruelty, such as fish being harmed and sea animals being killed. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, believes the Jolly Fisherman is loved by both adults and children and is seen as happy and friendly, and he doubts there will be much support for replacing it.
Scotland dominated possession and territory, scoring six tries to Georgia's two, including a penalty try, as they won 38-11 in a match where Georgia struggled with errors and disjointed play.

Widnes Vikings won against Castleford Tigers 38-12, with key tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Paddy Flynn, Lloyd White, Joe Mellor, Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick. Despite Castleford's strong second-half performance, Widnes held on to secure the victory, moving above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remains in sixth, one point above the Vikings.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel determined he was no longer a significant threat to the United States. He had been detained since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. Al-Odah challenged the US's right to detain him in the Supreme Court. Upon his release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and expressed no bitterness or anger, only excitement and joy at returning home. He will now spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. This release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148, the first since May when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl.

The passage describes the viral earworm "PPAP" performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The song, with its catchy beat, silly lyrics, and simple dance routine, quickly went viral on social media, amassing over 4 million views on YouTube and more than 44 million on Facebook. The song's unique concept and humorous nature led to widespread reactions, ranging from amusement to irritation, and inspired numerous tributes and covers by various artists. Despite its popularity, mainstream Japanese news sites have not extensively covered the phenomenon.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, particularly the Gallipoli landings. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. The service included the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia. The event, which began with King George V's attendance at a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, is significant for expatriates and visitors from Australia and New Zealand, honoring the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars.

Clarkson, 30, re-joins St Mirren from Premiership side Well, aiming to make his debut in the Championship against Alloa. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been fit and match-ready for the upcoming game. With nearly 400 senior appearances, including stints with Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, Clarkson is looking forward to contributing to St Mirren's push to improve their position in the Championship.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Concerns about the new ownership's stance on the existing workers' pension scheme were addressed, with assurances that current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, closed in 2004, is replaced by an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan's private office confirmed the continuation of current pension arrangements. Boparan aims to restore Bernard Matthews to a highly profitable business through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity for chicken processing.

The council leader announced a free crossing at Cowes until 2 July for a new ferry that has faced multiple issues, including breakdowns, grounding, and suspension due to training problems. The ferry, launched late on 14 May, has damaged cars and caused significant loss of trade for local businesses. Compensation for businesses is under discussion, and the council has authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to address vehicle scraping issues.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting concerns about access to UK waters and the need to avoid marginalization in broader Brexit negotiations. It notes that while Brexit could offer opportunities for the industry to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish exporter, challenges remain due to shared fish stocks with EU states and the need for continued market access. The report suggests that many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy should be retained post-Brexit, and that the UK must navigate potential differences in fisheries management regimes across England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the future prospects for British fishing following Brexit.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, admitted to downloading and permitting images of young boys in erotic poses between 2004 and 2014. He was placed on a community payback order, required to participate in a sex offender program, and put on the sex offenders register. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his conduct incompatible with teaching and deemed him unfit to teach, leading to his removal from the professional register for two years.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site following a March 2 blaze that disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire, citing the firm's non-compliance with fire safety laws. The company, run by Asset and Land Group, has until August 7 to appeal the decision. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the premises nine times in the past year, raising concerns about the fire's impact on residents, transport, and the environment. The EA revoked the environmental permit, effective August 7, requiring the company to remove all waste.

Syria is struggling to meet its deadline for destroying chemical weapons, with recent attacks on shipments and delays in handing over the stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad defended the government's actions, accusing the US of supporting terrorists, while the US and the OPCW express concern over the slow progress.

England won the fourth Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They scored 589-8 and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match, scoring 71 in the second innings and taking four catches. England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, calling it "an extraordinary player." The match was marked by England's strong batting and discipline, with Pakistan struggling on a pitch that favored the bowlers. England is expected to win the final test at Edgbaston on August 3, with the series currently tied.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is conducting a review to assess the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira aims to ensure that those accountable for residential care services understand the day-to-day realities and take necessary actions to improve the quality of life for older people. However, the Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment that no provider expert is included on the main advisory panel, potentially limiting sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, 39, has joined Aberdeen as player-manager, replacing Neil Cooper, after being chosen by Derek McInnes following a comprehensive process. Sheerin, who previously played for several Scottish clubs and coached Arbroath to their first national trophy in 2011, will return to the club where he began his playing career.

Swansea City appoints Curtis and Paul Williams to manage the match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club aims to appoint a new permanent boss soon, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis acknowledges the difficulty of avoiding relegation and the challenges of returning to the Premier League, citing the strength of the Championship and the competitive nature of clubs like Newcastle. Swansea's promotion in 2011 followed a significant rise from near bankruptcy and relegation in 2003, with Curtis noting the club's decline since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. He believes the current squad is capable of staying up and emphasizes the importance of staying up for the club and the local area.

Dr Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping into a competitive race, facing criticism from the scientific community. He founded private research institutes and a commercial company to expedite genetic research, publishing the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995. In 2006, he established the J Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form, Synthia, published in Science, while continuing to explore oceanic genetic diversity.

The Sutton Trust report highlights that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 out of 520,000 annually rated at level three. Compared to Germany, where over half of employers offer apprenticeships and 90% are equivalent to A-levels, England's system is less robust. The report calls for expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts each year, with the majority at level three or higher, and warns against the "cruel deception" of expanding apprenticeships without improving quality.

Storey won a cycling race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 golds, and has won 21 world titles across cycling and swimming. Storey aims for further Paralympic success in Rio de Janeiro and is targeting the road race on Saturday.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference Premier and will join Chester City in the Conference South following their failure to meet a deadline to pay football creditors. The Conference had offered a series of extensions to Hereford, who were taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar last week. Despite efforts to stay in the top flight, Hereford's financial woes, including debts of approximately £225,000, led to their relegation. Chester City, who were the last team expelled from the Conference, will now take the Bulls' place.

Milner, a former Manchester City player, has 61 caps for England, holding the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He made his senior debut in 2009 and played in two World Cups and two European Championships, including just three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music advocate, died at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it globally for over three decades and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's notable recordings include the 1980 Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, recognized as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. He was a pioneer in historically informed performance, influencing many leading orchestras and musicians, and was celebrated for his generosity, academic brilliance, and genial personality.

A Northern Irish boy, whose family wishes to keep his identity private, was removed from mainstream school due to poor coping and placed on a waiting list for a special school seat. All special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are currently full, with no timeline for availability. The boy's mother expressed concern that her son is isolated while his siblings attend school. A new classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, with hopes for the boy's enrollment soon. However, the family fears similar issues may arise for other families due to the over-subscribed nature of special needs schools. The Education Authority is reviewing special school placements but cannot comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns.

Newport Gwent Dragons are subject to a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), which aims to use Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, violating Football League rules. Newport Gwent Dragons have a lease agreement with the ground until 2023, and a shareholder vote on the takeover is scheduled for 9 May. The club is currently two points clear of relegation in the Football League with two games remaining.

The passage recounts the author's harrowing experiences during Sierra Leone's civil war, where he was kidnapped at 15 and trained by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels. He describes the brutal tactics used by the rebels, including threats of violence and cannibalism. After escaping, he lived in Freetown, engaging in petty crimes before meeting a preacher who encouraged him to rebuild his life. The author then became involved in the Ebola response in 2014, leading efforts to educate communities, provide food, and establish an Ebola treatment unit, which saved many lives. He reflects on his past mistakes and emphasizes the importance of investing in young people to build a better future.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, which faced auction to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, was saved through a public fundraising campaign that reached its target in a month. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrator Bob Young expressed satisfaction with the outcome, noting the spirit of goodwill and determination during the negotiations. The collection, important for Staffordshire and Britain's cultural development, would have been scattered globally if not for the successful fundraising.

Dan Groves mentioned that the "finer points" of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay are still being finalized. The club is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, just three points away from a play-off spot. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up, has played for several non-league clubs. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who plans to invest £10,000 a week. Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, decided to extend his term by one year after the Brexit referendum, balancing personal family considerations with professional responsibilities during the ongoing Brexit negotiations.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw, with Colchester taking the lead in the 12th minute and Blackpool equalizing from a corner in the 17th minute. Blackpool had several chances to win the game in injury time, but failed to capitalize, and Colchester finished with 10 men after a red card.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, teaches P6 and P7 children how to cope with change and stress, particularly in preparation for the transfer test and the transition to secondary school. The programme includes interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing, encourage seeking help when distressed, and identify sources of support. It also provides basic training for teachers in promoting emotional wellbeing. The initiative aims to be rolled out across Northern Ireland schools, addressing the stress and anxiety children face during the transition from primary to secondary education.

The disused Fawley power station chimney in Southampton, UK, could become the tallest structure south of London's Shard if transformed into the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development. The power station, which closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, was capable of powering one million homes. Developers plan to build a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, and restaurants, with fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Construction could begin in 2018 following an application for outline planning permission.

Latham won bronze in the men's scratch race at the Hong Kong championships, following Elinor Barker's silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats and missed the bronze-medal ride. Barker noted the young squad's positive progress despite not winning a medal.

Kemp returns to EastEnders to reunite the Mitchell family for Barbara Mitchell's final episodes, following her surprise return to Albert Square in 2010 and subsequent announcement of her death from cancer.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Tottenham lost 2-0 at Anfield, disappointing Spurs who have struggled away from home this season, winning only twice since September. Manager Pochettino criticized the team's lack of desire and fighting spirit, suggesting it makes it difficult to compete for the Premier League title. Chelsea could extend their lead if they beat Burnley, and Pochettino warned that a 12-point gap would be a significant problem.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts declared in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. This loss is the PDP's first in the presidential poll and in key northern states like Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa, which were affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. The PDP retained only eight governorships, mostly in the south-east, while the election in Imo state was inconclusive. The APC's victory has relegated the PDP to a regional party, with most states in the north and Lagos in the south-west going to the APC. However, the APC failed to win in Nigeria's five oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential disruptions to oil production and revenue. The elections were mostly peaceful, with 66 violent incidents reported, mostly in southern states. Buhari's victory is expected to bring significant changes, including the APC's control of Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital, for the first time since 1999.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19-22, offers an augmented reality app feature allowing visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews from festival items. The app also enables global interaction with the festival, providing updates, ticket purchasing, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. Head teachers at Trojan Horse schools faced challenges, including parents undermining authority and speaking to inspectors during Ofsted inspections. The Department for Education has terminated funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary, and warned Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British-Iranian woman, was sentenced to five years in a Tehran jail for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Iranian government. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticizes the UK government for insufficient action and reveals that an appeal against the sentence is being held in secret. Zaghari-Ratcliffe has been in solitary confinement since her arrest at Tehran Airport in April, and her two-year-old daughter, Gabriella, remains in Iran with her grandparents after her passport was confiscated. Ratcliffe fears for his wife's safety and believes she is being used as a bargaining chip in the diplomatic dispute between Iran and the UK. Amnesty International considers Zaghari-Ratcliffe a prisoner of conscience, and the organization hopes the appeal will result in her immediate release.

Optometrist Honey Rose is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter in the death of Vincent Barker, who died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution argues that Rose failed to detect swollen optic discs during the test and did not refer Barker for further investigation, leading to a build-up of fluid in his brain and his death. The court heard that the death was preventable if Rose had performed her duties properly.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he arranged through an adult website, filming their encounter. He also sent a sexually explicit message to the victim's sister on Christmas Day and was convicted of causing her and her parents to view sexual images and behaving threateningly. Weatherhogg, a first offender assessed as posing a moderate risk of re-offending, was placed on the sex offenders register and remitted to the High Court for sentencing.

Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida, with Stuart Thompson contributing 56 runs. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs remaining, with Samiullah Shenwari and Mohammad Shahzad key performers. The teams will face each other again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar from Santos, with his parents receiving £34m. The total cost, including various fees and taxes, is £106.8m. The club denies any tax-related wrongdoing and has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge's bodies were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. UK detectives, in collaboration with Thai police, are investigating the murders, with two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, allegedly confessing. The suspects face charges of murder, rape, and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty if convicted. The UK police visit was facilitated by Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, and concerns about the investigation's integrity, including DNA verification and mistreatment of suspects, have been raised by the UK Foreign Office.

The passage discusses various applications of virtual reality (VR) technology. It highlights how VR is being used by journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers to enhance understanding and engagement. The UK's National Autistic Society created a VR film to help the public understand autism, while Ikea used VR to allow users to virtually interact with a kitchen, including cooking meatballs. In healthcare, VR is used for teaching and treating phobias, with a study showing significant improvement in arachnophobia. Google launched Expeditions, a VR program for virtual field trips in education. VR start-ups are developing apps to improve language skills and engagement in learning, with potential to transform education by making lessons more interactive and immersive. However, challenges remain, including the cost of hardware and the need for more robust computing power.

The black box of the Su-24 jet, downed by Turkish F-16 fighters on November 24, was opened in Moscow for analysis. The investigation head, Nikolai Primak, stated that flight data appeared missing, which could clarify the jet's location at the time of the incident. This development comes amid heightened tensions between Russia and Turkey, with Russia imposing sanctions and accusing Turkey of US subservience and "creeping Islamization." The downing of the jet, which had a Russian crew, has led to a crisis, with Turkey insisting the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace. Both crew members ejected, but the pilot was killed, possibly by ground militants, while the navigator was rescued. Additionally, a Russian marine sent to rescue the crew was killed, and a helicopter was destroyed.

Scotland's women's national football team, led by forward Lauren Evans, is poised to reach the 2017 Women's World Cup finals after winning all five qualifiers. They face Iceland, the top-ranked team in their group, at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. Victory would secure their place in the tournament, avoiding the disappointment of previous play-off losses to Euro 2013 and the 2016 World Cup. The outcome of Friday's match and a return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20 will likely determine the group's top seed. Scotland, along with the best six of the remaining group runners-up, qualifies automatically for the Netherlands. Evans, who recently won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, emphasizes the importance of playing in top leagues for the team's development and the influence of international experience on the national team's style.

The review by Prof Kenneth Gibb for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found no "magic bullet" to fix the council tax system, noting its built-in problems from the start and the complications arising from its failure to be modified. The commission, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, will report back later this year. While property taxes are widely used and seen as stable and fair, they can be confusing and perceived as unfair. Local income taxes, though perceived as fairer, create income volatility for local authorities. The commission plans to hold a public consultation before publishing its report, aiming to explore fairer alternatives to the current council tax system, which the Scottish government considers unfair.

Apple is implementing a two-step verification process for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access to stolen celebrity photos, which were posted online after being stolen from iCloud. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after entering their username and password. The security measure aims to block attackers from downloading complete backups using tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple plans to encourage users to adopt two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Conservatives £2,980,815, the Liberal Democrats £1,580,575, Labour £1,027,339, and the Green Party £534,249 on their campaigns from January 23 to May 22. Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087, exceeding their 2009 spending.

Anderson, 27, cancels Barrow contract to join National League rivals. Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson, has international clearance pending. Gulls are four points above relegation zone with only one win in last six games.

An Irish-bred 10-year-old horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, suffering from severe pulmonary hemorrhage. Despite past symptoms of post-race ataxia, he had no significant underlying health issues. The British Horseracing Authority is investigating the cause and prevention of such rare incidents.

Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5 election, with Salmond emphasizing Scotland's diversity and unity, and McNeil warning of the need for learning from Westminster.

Emma Watson plays Belle, Harry Potter star Emma Watson plays Belle, Downton Abbey's Dan Stevens plays the Beast, Luke Evans plays Gaston, Josh Gad plays LeFou, Bill Condon directs, and the film is set to release in March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with victims' relatives to discuss intentions regarding charges against 23 suspects in the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, which killed 96 football fans. The meeting will follow the conclusion of new inquests that ruled the deaths unlawful. Evidence files for 15 suspects pertain to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster, while eight relate to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct. Relatives are awaiting decisions on whether charges will be brought.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis being common contraband. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges staff efforts to prevent contraband but emphasizes the need for additional measures, as requested by the Justice Secretary. A local resident reported witnessing packages thrown over the wall multiple times, and a former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband. However, the Ministry of Justice stated there is no evidence of drones entering the prison, and laws now allow up to two years in jail for smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's car while crossing the road to help a woman and her child. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The trial is ongoing.

Hellen Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies, which have exams in May. She finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir expressed her disappointment at missing the Commonwealths but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. She remains optimistic about her future, including potential Olympic aspirations and the possibility of competing in the 2018 World Indoor Championships.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a three-acre woodland area in Chapelizod, Dublin, has begun, involving excavations expected to last several weeks. CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance shows Deely talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland, where he worked. The man was later seen on Haddington Road, and detectives have appealed for the public's help to identify him.
Del Potro defeats Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in Wimbledon quarter-final, returning to top-level tennis after injury.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf, while Morocco's participation was reinstated after Cas overturned a ban. Morocco was initially banned for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, but the ban was reduced to a fine. Tunisia's dispute with Caf over a controversial penalty in their 2017 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea was resolved, allowing Tunisia to participate in the 2017 tournament.

McLaren, despite its current struggles and a fourth-place finish, has a rich history of success, including 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. The team's decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, but they seem to have regained their form with the car, though problems persist with the Honda power-unit. The team's partnership with Honda was one of their most successful eras, achieving multiple titles and victories.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, had a poor record, and the judge expressed concern over the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, hitting eight to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry added nine assists, while Klay Thompson scored 26 points. Meanwhile, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and 15 rebounds.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood by showcasing his impressive free-kick skills, wowing the team with his abilities.

Women with BRCA1 gene mutations, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed after a breast cancer diagnosis. A Canadian study found that BRCA1 carriers who underwent oophorectomy had a 62% reduction in breast cancer death and a 65% reduction in overall death risk. The protective effect was immediate and lasted 15 years. Oophorectomy is particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, when an Amtrak train hit them on the tracks. The train, No. 80, the Carolina, was en route from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, though one man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The couple, possibly homeless, were last seen with a grocery cart and items, seeking help to cross the tracks. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover DEA operative for 27 years, helping the agency carry out international sting operations. Promised U.S. citizenship, he now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo and fearing for his life if returned to Colombia.

The US body ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal actions related to the 'sucks' domain name, which is being used to target celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies to extort large sums of money. ICANN has sent a letter to US and Canadian regulators asking if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for 'sucks' domains on March 30, recommending a $2,499 annual fee, though most are sold for around $2,000. Celebrities and companies have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains.

A mother of a baby boy was arrested 27 years after his body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond. The boy's body was exhumed from his grave in Norfolk last year after the case came up for periodic review. DNA samples led police to the mother, who explained that the baby was stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. She placed the dead baby in the pond in the village of Weasenham St Peter on June 5, 1988, just days before it was found by teenagers. The case has been unsolved for 27 years until advances in DNA technology helped identify the mother. The woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from the moving car. The incident occurred in Bath, Somerset, when Mr. Young, believing Mr. Hicks was planning to flee without paying, drove him back to the taxi rank. When Mr. Hicks objected, the driver continued, leading Mr. Hicks to jump from the vehicle while it was traveling at over 20 mph. Mr. Justice Edis ruled that Mr. Young had unlawfully imprisoned Mr. Hicks, entitling him to damages, with the compensation expected to be around 50% of what the family requested, likely in the hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as storms produced twister reports, with one tornado reported near Goddard, Kansas, and others in southwestern Kansas. A potential tornado touched down near Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. Severe weather is expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a title shot. Rockhold plans to dominate Machida, who prefers to dance and run around, by cutting him off and gradually applying pressure, exploiting Machida's weaknesses. Both fighters acknowledge mutual respect for each other's skills, with Rockhold emphasizing his marathon training and readiness to chase down Machida. Machida remains confident in his ability to win and potentially earn a title shot, despite Rockhold's strong performance.

An aircraft landed without its landing gear deployed, skidding on the runway in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane's propellers hit the ground, causing damage, but the pilot managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, eventually landing safely in Fort Lauderdale. The incident is believed to be due to human error, and the FAA is investigating.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment with Yaya Toure's performance but vowed to support him until the end of the season. City is considering offers for Toure as they seek to address an aging squad. The team faces West Ham, with defeat potentially allowing Liverpool to close the gap to one point. City goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged player responsibility, and Hart praised Pellegrini's leadership. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell against joining City, citing the limited playing time of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will remain in the UK after his seven-year prison sentence was dropped, allowing his European Arrest Warrant to be withdrawn. Convicted in 1999 for his role in the mafia, Rancadore lived in Britain for over 20 years under the alias Marc Skinner. His case expired in October 2014, leading to the withdrawal of the warrant and his release from extradition proceedings.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, with six rivals. It will be Mr. Mole's last ride in a Grade One race for AP McCoy, who announced his retirement after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February.

The mother of Marcia Trimble, who was murdered 40 years ago, recently saw crime scene photos of her daughter's body and expressed a desire for revenge against her killer, Jerome Sydney Barrett. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Barrett in 1975, and her body was found 33 days later. Despite her then-husband advising her against seeing the body and photos, Virginia Trimble Ritter finally viewed them with the help of the lead investigator. Barrett, who was 15 at the time of the crime, was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam. He regards his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, which led to his first major win at the U.S. Open that year. McIlroy is aiming to become the sixth player to win all four major titles, following Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. He tees off at the Arnold Palmer Invitational in Orlando on March 19, focusing on playing his best to achieve his long-standing goal of winning the Masters.

Rainbows appeared in the New York area after heavy rain, exotic dancers are being banned at wakes in rural China, RDJ became agitated during a UK interview, the Kylie Jenner lip challenge trended, 102-year-old Alice Barker relived her prom with filmmakers, a prom-posal referencing bombs sparked controversy, Johnny Depp's unrecognizable look in the 'Black Mass' trailer was noted, a pregnant woman referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" to announce her pregnancy, and a military dad photobombed his son's photo.

272 children in England were hospitalized due to fetal alcohol syndrome over the past year, with the actual number potentially much higher. WHO research suggests at least 1 in 100 UK babies may suffer learning, behavioral, and physical issues from maternal alcohol exposure, totaling about 7,500 annually. Children with the syndrome do not improve and are often underdiagnosed. Medical issues linked to prenatal alcohol exposure include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, vision loss, and epilepsy. Pregnant women are advised not to drink alcohol, with a maximum of two units twice a week if consumption is necessary.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, known as "Boomerang Boy," attempted to rob a post office in Shildon, County Durham, on March 15. He was tackled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, and disarmed by his wife, Sam, who struck him with a baseball bat. The would-be robber was arrested by the police who arrived minutes later, and McKerry, who had a history of juvenile offenses, was sentenced to six years in jail for attempted robbery.

Four Royal Navy sailors from the UK have been charged with gang rape at a Canadian barracks party and must stay in Nova Scotia until their trial. The sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, where they were given bail conditions including living at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax for several years, surrendering their passports, and not contacting the victim or six witnesses. They face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which carry up to 14 years in prison. The British government has agreed to a deal allowing them to continue working for the Royal Navy while their case is processed.

A mother in Las Vegas, Valerie Jackson, was falsely accused of child abuse after a stranger mistook her four-year-old son RJ Jackson's symptoms of Netherton's Syndrome, a rare skin condition, for signs of abuse. The condition causes RJ's skin to appear red and scaly, and Valerie has to regularly apply creams to alleviate his symptoms. Despite the diagnosis and her efforts to care for RJ, she faces public ignorance, taunts, and even police involvement when a member of the public reported her to the authorities.

The controversial Protein World adverts featuring a bikini-clad model have been removed from London Underground after receiving over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and numerous complaints about promoting an unhealthy body image. The Advertising Standards Authority has received 216 complaints, and the company has noted the backlash from customers. The removal of the posters coincides with a protest against Protein World in Hyde Park on May 2, with hundreds expected to attend. The campaign has sparked significant debate on social media, with some defending the brand and others criticizing it for promoting unrealistic body standards and sexism.

Rail firms are planning significant fare hikes, up to 87%, just ten days after the general election, despite pledges from main party leaders to freeze prices. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to almost double some fares on the London-Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency. This has angered Cameron's constituents, prompting his personal intervention. Other notable hikes include a 24.5% increase for a return between Stafford and Liverpool on Virgin trains.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, was blinded in one eye after thugs threw a brick through his front door while he confronted them about throwing stones at his property in Oldham. The attack occurred three weeks after his marriage to Elaine, with whom he had moved into their new home. The police have launched an investigation but found no clear motive, suggesting the incident might have been "yobs messing around."

Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension with Derbyshire after returning from a leg injury sustained in a road accident that killed his father in April 2014. He missed the entire 2014 season and underwent an ankle operation, making his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and work ethic, expressing delight at his return and confidence in his continued good form.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, battled cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer, Harley wore a superhero mask during his treatment to feel stronger. After a year of intensive chemotherapy, surgery, and stem cell transplant, doctors declared him cancer-free. His story gained worldwide attention, including a gift from Nickelodeon. Harley's bravery earned him a Cancer Research UK Little Star Award and made him the face of their Kids and Teens campaign.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future, praising Grealish's performance in the FA Cup semi-final against Liverpool. Grealish is currently under consideration for both the Republic of Ireland and England, but Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish should continue to play for Villa to earn more first-team opportunities before making his international decision.

The passage discusses the high landing fees at certain airports for private jets, with the most expensive being Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, which charges £4,559 for landing a 767-400 jet. Other expensive airports include Narita and Kansai in Japan, as well as Bristol Airport in the UK, Toronto Pearson in Canada, and Darwin International Airport in Australia. These fees reflect the popularity of these airports among the wealthy and the growing trend of private jet travel.

A video shows Cooper, a Labrador, eating an ice cream cone at McDonald's in one bite while his pal Daisy takes a few licks. Owner Katie Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, notes that Cooper always eats quickly and often enjoys fast food treats like pup-uccinos from Starbucks. The video has garnered over seven million views.
Gary Locke, former Hearts boss, has been appointed permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year deal after a successful interim spell.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to essential oils he uses to help manage his condition. Teachers reportedly warned that the oils, manufactured by DoTerra, were distracting and caused smells in the classroom. Kemp applies the oils to Logan's head and neck, believing they help him stay calm and focused. Despite receiving a letter from the school board stating the oils created a "problem" for staff and students, Kemp plans to continue using the oils, arguing that natural scents should not be restricted. The Lake County School District has stated they will not suspend Logan, citing it as a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper Complex, was destroyed by a powerful fire on Wednesday at 3 PM. The blaze spread through 90 condos, causing intense smoke to pour over Westhampton Beach and be visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames but were unable to enter the buildings. The fire was so intense that it melted paint off nearby structures. The complex, used as holiday homes by residents between May and November, was devastated, leaving residents and the building manager, Rob Taber, devastated. The fire chief is investigating the incident, which is believed to have started near a car parked by the complex.

The Queen, at 88, was spotted riding her black fell pony Carlton LIma Emma through Windsor Great Park, enjoying the spring sunshine despite her age. She is a lifelong equestrian, having first ridden at age four, and remains an avid rider and breeder of fell ponies and Highland ponies. The Queen, who never wears a riding helmet, prefers to ride in a silk scarf. Her riding has decreased somewhat due to a knee injury, but she remains a familiar sight at Windsor Stables and takes a keen interest in her horses, some of which are now ridden by her grandchildren.

A Brisbane neighbor dispute over noise escalated into a fatal punch, killing 55-year-old Leon Yeman. Phillip Pama, 28, was charged with manslaughter after allegedly striking Yeman during an argument in front of their homes. Pama, a shift worker, was granted conditional bail and ordered to surrender his passport, follow a curfew, and report to police twice weekly. The case is set for a return hearing on May 18.

Jilted 52-year-old music teacher Yulia Simonova wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the hit and detailed her sadistic plans, including breaking his limbs and causing him unbearable pain. Police set up a sting operation, filming Simonova's conversation with an undercover officer who posed as the hitman. She was arrested and faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief at the arrest, hoping the police "throw away the key" for Simonova's prison cell.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea Football Manager, prays daily with his wife Matilde but never discusses football or his professional life with her. He speaks to God about personal matters and maintains a strong faith, visiting church only when he feels the need. Mourinho emphasizes his belief in being a good person beyond his professional persona, acknowledging mistakes but stressing that his life extends beyond football.
Bob Barker returned to host "The Price is Right" for the first time in eight years, hosting the classic "Lucky Seven" game before handing over to Drew Carey.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday for attempted burglary and destruction of property at a residential address on D Street SE. Baldwin, who works with the Foreign Missions Branch of the Secret Service, was revoked of his security clearance and placed on leave following the arrest. The incident occurred two days after a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for alleged misconduct, with the Department of Homeland Security's Inspector General investigating both cases.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, captured images of a hungry lion at the city's safari park by creeping within 10 feet of the animal while lying on the ground with only a camera. The lion's presence was alerted by the camera's shutter, prompting Saeed to quickly retreat to safety.

An unidentified woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious and died on a Brooklyn street near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue on March 22. She had no identification and a distinctive tattoo of the name "Monique" across a heart with a rose on her right leg. The NYPD has released images of the tattoo to aid in identifying the woman, and anyone with information is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK, where they couldn't afford to buy property. They constructed the wood and steel house over a year and a half, using a steel frame and gradually adding details like stained glass windows. The home, located in Nelson, is surrounded by nature and powered mostly by solar panels, with a wood-fired stove and water sourced from a nearby spring. The project cost about $25,000, and the couple plans to build another similar home.

Children who share iPads in class outperform those who do not in early literacy tests, according to researchers. The study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads scored 30 points higher than those who used devices individually or not at all. The collaborative learning around shared technology appears to be key to the improved outcomes.
A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front legs, balancing while foraging for food and charming onlookers in China.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released from the infield care center. Dracone, who spun out while exiting his pit box, did not finish the race and finished 23rd. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain that had fallen for hours before the green flag.

A 32-year-old man in Rio de Janeiro, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his 29-year-old dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by repeatedly smashing her head into concrete and shooting her in the face. He confessed the act was driven by jealousy over men looking at her. The couple had been married for only four days when the incident occurred.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, including anxiety and depression, in a candid interview. She revealed that these issues, compounded by stress, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation, drove her to believe her life was no longer worth living. Wilson now accepts she is an "anxious person" and emphasizes the need to acknowledge the link between depression and anxiety to better address the increasing rates of stress and anxiety affecting Australian women.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant, will no longer face prosecution after she beat her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014 upon discovering her using heroin in the bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the second-degree assault charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin's defense attorney noted the ex-girlfriend had a history of harassment and threats against Curtin. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.
A Pit Bull named Gemma was filmed in California being fed treats, but when her owner threw in a broccoli spear to trick her, Gemma showed disgust by eating and then spitting out the vegetable.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page, which occurred when the young entrepreneur awards page was scrapped in 2011 and the organizers allowed the registration to expire. The bank removed the hyperlink and issued an apology, stating it had no association with the external site.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom when their home in Clinton caught fire on Sunday morning. Marcus called 911, providing firefighters with crucial instructions during an 11-minute call, helping himself and his sister to be rescued. Prince George's County firefighters entered the room by breaking a window and safely rescued the siblings, with Marcus being handed out the window and his sister receiving a gas mask from him. The three other family members escaped on their own. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members were taken to Medstar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae lit up Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay and Sydney's Manly Beach, creating a neon glow. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the scene as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, is a single-celled phytoplankton that glows as a defense mechanism and typically blooms in spring and autumn due to natural causes.

New genetic tests for breast cancer can determine a patient's risk of recurrence, potentially sparing them chemotherapy. These tests, such as Endopredict, analyze tumor markers and can indicate a low risk of recurrence (as low as 5%). If a low risk is identified, patients can opt out of chemotherapy, which often involves significant side effects. Currently available privately for about £2,500, these tests aim to become NHS-approved, potentially saving costs and improving patient choice.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including at least one from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships also had emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. This follows the case of Commander Sarah West, who was flown back to the UK after claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with three becoming the first female submariners in 2014. Pregnant women are typically evacuated from war zones, often on flights reserved for injured troops.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The incident occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved restarting two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, more than four years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular among many Japanese, who view nuclear energy as too dangerous. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium, was spotted on the roof of Abe's residence. The government is reviewing how to prevent future terrorism threats from drones, especially as the country prepares for the Olympics and G7 summit.
A Chinese security guard takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother to work on his motorbike every day, ensuring her safety and companionship, as there is no one else to care for her.

The study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise among women. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men in a single occasion within the past month, also rose sharply, particularly among women. The study highlights changing social norms and economic factors, such as the influx of affluent professionals in cities and the decreasing cost of alcohol, as contributing to the increase in binge drinking. Despite the rise in heavy drinking, the overall percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively stable. The study analyzed data from over 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting women's and babies' health at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily, despite the associated risks of infections and death. Currently, over a quarter of women in England have a caesarean, a rate more than doubled since the early 1990s, with many opting for planned procedures due to anxiety. WHO advises the caesarean rate should be between 10-15%, citing dangers and costs, and criticizes the lack of medical necessity in many cases.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners at a yard sale. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The home, estimated to be worth $800,000, had a broken window and other signs of disturbance. Police recovered numerous items, including furniture, appliances, and a painting, and are asking anyone who received such items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was recovered after police posted humorous selfies and messages on her Facebook page, using the unlocked phone to track her down. The phone was handed in at an Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border after Bella lost it at a friend's birthday party the night before. Police used the phone to post updates, including a photo of it in a holding cell, and reassured Bella that it was safe. Bella reclaimed her phone without needing to provide her name, as officers recognized her from her Facebook page.

A five-day-old baby hippo was tragically killed after being caught in a fight between two adult males at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface, with its mother watching in horror. Despite the mother's efforts to protect her baby, the adult hippos overwhelmed it, leading to the calf's death hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, priced at £575,000, has only three years left on its lease, making it a bargain compared to neighboring properties. The property, described as bright and well-proportioned, includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, and 1,990 sq/ft of space. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. However, significant renovation is required, and buyers would need to negotiate a lease extension with the freeholder, potentially costing between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, leading to free drink giveaways. The outage, caused by a system refresh failure, began on Friday evening and lasted until Saturday morning. While some customers enjoyed the freebies, many stores closed early to avoid giving away free products. The incident occurred a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings.

Terrorists are using rural areas in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, Wales, for training and radicalization. These locations, which include military training sites, are also being used to prepare individuals for extremist activities. Community members who participate in ordinary activities may have hidden ulterior motives. Historical incidents, such as the training of 7/7 bombers and arrests of would-be terrorists, highlight the ongoing threat of Islamic extremism in the region.

An Omura's whale, a species previously thought to be extinct, was found dead on a beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first confirmed sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. DNA profiling helped identify the 5.68-meter juvenile female. The discovery is significant for whale scientists as very little is known about the species, which is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further study and possibly public display.

The passage discusses concerns about female presidential candidates, particularly Hillary Clinton, being influenced by their hormones, which some argue could impair their judgment and leadership. It highlights a CEO's belief that women's hormones make them unsuitable for high-stakes decisions, contrasting this with historical examples of male leaders whose hormones led to poor decisions. The text also points out that women leaders tend to take fewer risks and that studies show women are less likely to engage in unethical behavior. Despite this, there is a broader discussion about gender bias in the workplace, which can limit women's opportunities and success. The passage emphasizes that while women are increasingly represented in education and the workforce, they still face significant bias that can affect their careers and leadership roles. It concludes by noting that gender equality benefits everyone, leading to stronger companies, healthier families, and more successful marriages.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his extensive collection of over 200 antiques, including a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, paintings, furniture, swords, and more, in a £100,000 auction to downsize his home. Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow. The auction, featuring 238 lots, will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire on Saturday.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery on law enforcement and with a history of bipolar mental illness and attempted suicide, is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day his mother was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. An out-of-state family member called for a well-being check, leading to the discovery of her body. Shemansky is now on the run, and authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed the method of death. His estranged wife is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home.

Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a perceived unique strategic opportunity. The decision was made by the IAAF Council, who saw it as a chance to access a key market and promote global development of athletics.

An aspiring model, Leonie Granger, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger lured Hassan to his flat, where she and her accomplices, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, tied him up, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home to steal his hidden winnings. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by the judge.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas struggled significantly during the second half of the season, particularly in his country's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Despite expressing happiness in London earlier, his form has dipped from his strong performance around Christmas, where he looked set to break the Barclays Premier League record for assists. Given just four out of ten by a Spanish newspaper, Fabregas' poor form continues, raising questions about his durability. His decline in performance has affected his role as a key playmaker for Chelsea, who are still aiming for the Premier League title.

West Ham are close to signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a trial with the club's academy. Beckford, who has offers from clubs in Belgium, is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean and has been linked with several European clubs. Meanwhile, West Ham will offer season tickets at £289, making it the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League for the 2016-17 season as they prepare to move to their new 54,000-capacity stadium.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. Lane, who was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, condemned the decision as "pathetic." The attack, which occurred at Everleigh near Amesbury, left Lane with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite a video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of saboteurs, Wiltshire Police have shelved the investigation pending further information. This decision has dismayed hunt supporters across the country.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece of Al-Qaeda, was a prominent U.S. citizen and Al-Qaeda operative who spoke against his country on behalf of the terrorist organization. Born in 1978, Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998. He rose through the ranks of Al-Qaeda, becoming a key English-language propagandist, issuing threats against the U.S. and Western interests. Indicted for treason in 2006, Gadahn appeared in multiple Al-Qaeda videos criticizing the U.S. and its actions. He was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January, along with another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, and two hostages.

A five-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, has become a viral sensation for his exceptional basketball skills, having played since the age of two and a half. His impressive performance has garnered widespread admiration and praise, with many comparing him to the country's former basketball star Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) and a key member of the organization that campaigned for child sex legalization in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation, which was chaired by comedian John Cleese. Hacked Off, set up following the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation, advocating for a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson inquiry.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall, showcasing a collection of ten pieces of unisex clothing designed to be worn in 20 different ways. The show, held on a warm 28 degrees Celsius day, was attended by guests who enjoyed nibbles and drinks from the club, with the backdrop of the ocean and beautiful blue sky.

Boxer Amir Khan, his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa visited a safari park in Northern California, posing with animals and enjoying family time. Khan announced his next fight will be against Chris Algieri on May 30.

A Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, has been removed from an Israeli memorial after his family and others complained. Abu Khdeir was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, and his name appeared on the memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl. His family objected, stating that no permission was sought before listing his name. Almagor, an organization representing terror victims, also opposed his inclusion, describing his death as a "rogue attack" and not a terror victim. The organization demanded his name be removed, and the National Insurance Institute of Israel complied, taking his name off the memorial following complaints.

A California-based YouTube user filmed his young son repeatedly using his cat's belly as a makeshift pillow while trying to get some rest in the garden. The cat initially licks its fur before the boy sits on it, but after a brief moment, the cat moves to another spot, prompting the boy to follow. The sequence repeats until the cat finally leaves, after which the boy and the cat reconcile, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer and police corruption trial witness, lost his coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about selling marijuana and alleging that undercover officers stole money and drugs from him. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, Kushner acknowledged being arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to probation, but maintains his innocence. He is one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government about police wrongdoing in the trial.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in China's Fujian province injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene, a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, with no reported toxic chemical spill. Five of the injured were treated for broken glass, and over 600 firefighters contained the fire. The plant has faced protests over its construction, leading to relocation due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low and children's-sized shinpads due to superstition. He made his first Premier League start for Villa against QPR, expressing satisfaction with the opportunity despite the tough match.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered global and irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother. She remains unresponsive and in a tracheostomy, though no longer in a medically induced coma. Her condition has not improved, despite her father's claims of improvement.

Russia are on the brink of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Germany's Sabine Lisicki on Saturday. Pavlyuchenkova also had problems on serve, racking up 13 double faults, but still managed to win 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Russia needs one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and secure a first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm, predicted to hit later this week, is expected to bring heavy rain. The same weather system that caused significant flooding and high winds last week is now forecast to return, potentially hampering clean-up efforts and raising flood levels. The State Emergency Service (SES) is particularly concerned about the impact on the hard-hit Hunter region and urges the community to prepare their homes and families.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, posted photos of bruising on her Instagram, leading to claims she attempted suicide. She clarified that she was treated in a hospital for low blood pressure after falling and hitting her head, and her boyfriend was in Naples at the time. Italian media reported the suicide attempt, but Moric denied it, stating she was recovering at home.

The passage discusses a new poll revealing that Diana is the favorite name for the second child of Prince William and Kate Middleton, with 12% of respondents preferring the name for a girl. Alice and Charlotte are also popular choices. For a boy, James is the top preference. Many people hope for a girl, with a quarter of those polled wanting a female baby. The poll also shows strong support for William taking six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded dozens in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, near a group of protesters in Khost city. An Afghan lawmaker was among the wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group claimed the attack. The victims were heading to a larger protest against the provincial governor.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back, is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves, 31, has been with Barcelona for seven successful years, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, he and his agent were unable to agree on a new deal, leading to his departure from the club.
