Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old player currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join his club. Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a great fit for Boca Juniors, praising their South-American style and the fans' love for them. Pirlo is known for his exceptional midfield skills, while Totti, a Roma legend, would be well-received in Argentina.

Lee Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. The fall, which made him an internet sensation, left him with only a nose cut. Despite the incident, Ferguson was back riding and is undeterred, joking about potential future career paths in gymnastics.

James Haskell, the England flanker, dressed as Iron Man in a serious Instagram post following the release of the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie, which premiered at Westfield London shopping centre on Tuesday evening. The movie featured an A-list cast including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who previously played for Wasps, Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders in New Zealand, returned to Wasps for the 2012 season after his international career. Since then, he has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide leg trousers as a key trend in spring/summer 2015, noting their effortless appeal and versatility. It highlights how this style offers an alternative to the long-standing popularity of skinny jeans, with examples from designers like Stella McCartney, Gucci, and Topshop. The text also provides styling tips, emphasizing the importance of proportion and the use of high heels to enhance the look.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with screening "American Sniper" despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it. The film, starring Bradley Cooper, was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history. Kyle was killed in 2013 at a Texas shooting range. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq War negatively portrayed the Middle East and its people. The university's detroit metropolitan area is home to the nation's largest Arab-American population. A counter-petition was created to reverse the decision to cancel the movie, and the university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and that it would go ahead as planned. An alternative, family-friendly film, "Paddington," would be offered for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper." The announcement was praised by Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3, using a lighter to ignite an aerosol spray. The quokka survived but was singed. The men, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty and evicted from the island. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer in New York nightspots during the 1930s and 1940s, was shown early music videos (soundies) of herself for the first time by filmmakers Mark Cantor and volunteers. Barker, who had never seen any of the films or her own photographs and memorabilia, was delighted by the experience.

The passage discusses a decline in the British practice of washing one's own car, with a third of men admitting they have never done so. A survey of 1,100 adults found that 31% of men have never washed their car, and only 12% of those who do wash their own cars do so regularly. Reasons for the decline include the rise of Sunday car wash shops, more live football on TV, the availability of hand car washes, and the size of modern vehicles. Brits are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, particularly in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield. The article notes that the tradition of Sunday car washing is fading, with many opting for automated machines or professional services instead.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard's impact at Liverpool since 2008, believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world, and that Liverpool can find replacements. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal, potentially signing off his Anfield career on his birthday.

Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole in one on the 130-yard fourth hole at Augusta National during the par-3 contest of the Masters, becoming the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963 and collecting his sixth green jacket in 1986.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as storms produced reports of twisters, with one tornado reported near Goddard, Kansas, and others in southwestern Kansas. A tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. More storms are forecast for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and the southern Great Lakes region.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates was granted permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which angered Harris's family, who accused Bates of showing apathy during their time of mourning. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor, 26, is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas. McGregor has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach and claims Aldo lacks the motivation to defend his belt. McGregor previously challenged Aldo for the title, which Aldo will attempt to defend for the eighth time.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was criticized by anti-drinking campaigners for glorifying binge drinking after he cheered a crowd by skolling a beer at an Australian rules function. Cultural studies professor Julie Roberts argued that this behavior sets up a culture where drinking is about how quickly and how much one can consume, rather than socializing with friends. Critics also noted that Abbott's actions could perpetuate the stereotype that heavy drinking is a defining trait of being an "Aussie bloke." Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, emphasizing his commitment to fitness and setting a positive example.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positives tied to Scott County, up from 106 last week. The rise is linked to a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence, primarily affecting intravenous drug users using the painkiller Opana. Health officials expect more cases as testing increases, potentially pressuring Pence to extend the 30-day program. The county typically sees about five HIV cases annually. Since the program's approval, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants, with about 1,400 used syringes returned. The future of the program and similar legislation in other counties remains uncertain, with Pence opposing needle exchanges and some lawmakers questioning their effectiveness and funding sustainability.

The passage describes an Arsenal fan who made his girlfriend take a detailed test about the club, scoring 87% and impressing him with her knowledge. He rewarded her by not dumping her, and she shared the experience on Twitter, garnering praise from fellow football fans.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover DEA operative for 27 years, helping carry out international sting operations. Promised U.S. citizenship, he now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo and fearing for his life if deported to Colombia.

A 14-year-old girl in India was allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village in Uttar Pradesh and subsequently set herself on fire, sustaining 70% burns. She is currently fighting for her life in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. Her family reportedly told her to keep the incident quiet. The accused men have been arrested. This incident has heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the banning of the documentary "India's Daughter," which detailed the gang rape and murder of an Indian student in Delhi. Recent attacks have led to street protests demanding more protection for women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal will not field Robin van Persie in Sunday's derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal also ruled out Luke Shaw from the match. The derby, which could see Manchester United finish as high as second or third in the league, is a significant opportunity for Van Gaal to secure a strong league position and avoid a Champions League qualifying match.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Barclays Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest, organized by fan groups, coincided with the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Fans displayed banners criticizing the high ticket prices, which started at £64 for the lunchtime kick-off, and expressed frustration over the rising costs of following their clubs. Organizers called the prices "extortionate" and demanded tangible reductions in line with working-class incomes.

A newborn baby with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, was saved after receiving a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister. Diagnosed shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, the infant's condition worsened despite initial jaundice, leading to the need for a liver transplant. Neither parent was a suitable match, but the maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered to donate part of her liver, successfully saving the baby's life.

Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake won the first two rounds of Audi's Football Challenge against teammates Loic Remy and Willian, securing a 6-0 lead. In the final challenge, Willian and Remy achieved a surprising victory, with Willian causing a minor accident by smashing a wing mirror on one of the Audi cars.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger, who was a high-powered executive with PPG Industries, Sprint Corp., Delphi Corp., and General Electric Co., pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault. He claimed he was not suicidal on the day of the crash, stating he was trying to take his own life. Prosecutors argued he was depressed and impaired by medications. Dellinger faces up to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit from the victims' estate.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, sparing her the maximum 25 years to life. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and desire for her to be placed in general population on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison. The judge noted Spears suffers from a mental illness and described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors argued that Spears intentionally made her son ill due to a need for attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent and planned to appeal the verdict.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against two new strains (H3N2 and B/Phuket) due to a spike in flu-related deaths in the northern hemisphere. The vaccine, expected to arrive a month later than anticipated, will be available for free to high-risk groups from April 20. Experts believe the modified vaccine will provide better protection and help prevent more deaths.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts due to Illinois' financial crisis, as the state considers eliminating the Historic Preservation Agency that manages the site. The tomb, designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone significant repairs and renovations totaling over $2.5 million, maintaining excellent physical condition. Despite this, the National Geographic portrayal of the tomb as lacking historical character has sparked debate among visitors and caretakers.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 90s and early 2000s fashion trends, including bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. It highlights how celebrities and young stars are reinterpreting these trends, often taking them to the extreme or incorporating them into modern styles.

The passage summarizes a variety of trending stories from the past week, including rainbows appearing in the New York area, a crackdown on hiring exotic dancers in rural China, RDJ's reaction to a UK interviewer, the popularity of lip plumping, 102-year-old Alice Barker reliving her prom, Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast, Johnny Depp's unrecognizable look in the Black Mass trailer, a unique pregnancy announcement referencing The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air, and a military dad photobombing his son.

Serena Williams reached her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, celebrated with a giant cake. She advanced to the semi-finals, facing Simona Halep, after defeating Sabine Lisicki in a three-set match. Williams will play Halep for a spot in the final, while Andy Murray celebrated his 500th career win with a cake.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani cafe owner and advocate for free speech, was killed by gunmen in Karachi after closing her second-floor cafe. She was known for hosting discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, which made her a target in Pakistan where free speech is dangerous. Mahmud's shooting, along with her mother's injury, sparked widespread grief and admiration across the country, with many viewing her as a symbol of humanism, love, and tolerance. Her cafe, the second floor (T2F), served as a hub for those seeking secular wisdom and freedom of thought, and her death was mourned on social media and through various tributes.

82-year-old Mangu Ram, a Hindu traditional healer, has lived in a slum in Jammu, India's only Muslim-majority state, for 70 years, denied citizenship rights and unable to own property or vote. Despite being refugees from the partition of India, he and thousands like him now hope for change after the Hindu nationalist BJP won power in Kashmir. The West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), mostly Hindus from Punjab, have been denied rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the state. With the BJP's pledge to normalize WPR status, there is hope for improved conditions, though activists warn of taking matters into their own hands if hopes are dashed.

Tokyo FC forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly made an offer around £4 million for the 22-year-old. Muto, who recently scored the winning goal against Shonan Bellmare, is keen to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has acknowledged knowing Muto but declined to comment on the transfer. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, praised his intelligence, speed, and confidence, suggesting he could be a significant addition to Stamford Bridge.

Australia has dropped a policy preventing the selection of its best players who play overseas, highlighting England's outdated stance. Stuart Lancaster, England's coach, should be free to pick the best players regardless of their location. Players like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage have excelled abroad, improving their game and performance. The argument is that if players are happier, healthier, and better overseas, they should be supported and considered for the squad. This approach aligns with the goal of selecting the world's best team for the World Cup, avoiding "what ifs" and ensuring the best chance of winning.

Open Garden developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster to enhance message transmission in wireless mesh networks, addressing the limitations of Firechat's message range.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle, in a TED talk, advocates for body positivity by embracing the term "fat" as a self-descriptor, emphasizing it should not equate to ugliness. She highlights the rise in size discrimination in the workplace and early childhood aspirations among girls to be thinner. Lillian believes increased exposure to body diversity fosters acceptance and positive perceptions. She began performing burlesque in 2012, finding empowerment and body positivity, and encourages others to draw courage from their own moments of bravery. Despite some negative comments, her talk has garnered widespread positive feedback and has inspired viewers to reevaluate their body image.

Arsenal winger Theo Walcott, who has been on the bench for most of the season, participated in a Lanvin photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and runway model Olga Sherer. Walcott, who has been substituted in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games, came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea. He will be hoping to make his first start for Arsenal when they face Hull on Monday.

An auction featuring over 400 props and puppets created by legendary makeup artist Rick Baker will take place on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from films such as "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," "Harry and the Hendersons," "Gremlins 2: The New Batch," and "Batman & Robin," as well as from Michael Jackson's "Moonwalker" and music videos. High-value items include the "Alien Edgar Bug" from "Men in Black" valued at $40,000, the "Two-Face Mask" from "Batman Forever" valued at $1,500, and the "Grinch Costume" from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" listed at $8,000.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died after falling from a 164ft drop while skiing with his family in the French Alps. Separated from his mother, Carwyn ventured into dense woodland and fell, leaving his family devastated and a vast void in their hearts. Carwyn was described as daring, outgoing, and determined, with a handsome smile that brightened any room. His family, from Wales, had been enjoying a ski holiday in Flaine when the tragedy occurred.

A 15-year-old anorexic girl, Laura Scurr, from Whitley Bay, survived on just one piece of fruit a day, hiding food and lying to her mother about eating. Her obsession with being a "size zero" led to severe health issues, including collapsing and being placed on a heart machine. After a week in intensive care, she received support from eating disorder organizations and has since recovered, speaking out about the pressures on young girls to be thin.

Liverpool unveiled a new home kit designed by US sports brand New Balance, marking the first offering from the company to replace sister company Warrior as the club's suppliers. The new gingham design was presented to fans at Anfield on Friday, with players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet unveiling the kit. Sterling was specifically told by supporters to remain at the club, despite his recent interview where he rejected a new £100,000-a-week deal and hinted at potential interest from Arsenal. The new kit features all-white branding and a new collar style, with the club's legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush also present at the launch.

The University of Manchester has produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, revealing clumps of mystery particles across 0.4% of the sky. The map, created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES) aimed at mapping 12.5% of the sky to study dark matter and dark energy. The survey uses gravitational lensing to detect dark matter's gravitational effects on galaxies, with the goal of mapping dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky and eventually creating a 3D view of the cosmos.

Manchester United has made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, aiming to sign the 21-year-old winger. United manager Louis van Gaal, familiar with Depay's skills from Holland's 2014 World Cup campaign, is keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also attracting interest from other top European clubs.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team in the Youth Cup final, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The young City players, despite a strong performance, struggled to match Chelsea's dominance.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference but contends that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He argues that states should regulate marriage and that political debates should decide any changes, rather than courts. Despite his stance, Rubio stated he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, emphasizing respect for their choices.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple, respectively, embarked on an open-ended cycling adventure around the world, starting from Manchester. They aim to explore different parts of the planet, one pedal at a time, living on less than three euros per day and relying on free accommodation. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles across 16 countries, including Spain, France, Italy, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and across the Pacific.

A Texas couple sued Premiere Photos owner James Evans for allegedly printing a racial slur on wedding photos. The couple, who wish to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue Evans after learning of the offensive caption many months after the event. The incident occurred at a rented photo booth, and the couple was not informed until their sister revealed it. Evans allegedly did not apologize and told the couple to "sue" him. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is uncertain about his return to action after suffering a concussion during a match against Italy in February. He is cautious about rushing back to avoid long-term injury risks, similar to other players like Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling. Brown emphasizes the importance of understanding concussion symptoms and the dangers of playing while still recovering, which influenced his decision to withdraw from a match against Ireland. He advocates for honesty and prioritizing health over performance.

The passage suggests that smartphone use and increased connectivity have contributed to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among British couples, with couples now having sex three times a month compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. This decline is attributed to the blurring of boundaries between public and private life, constant connectivity, and the resulting busier schedules that leave less time for intimacy.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued at up to £1.2 million each, are now facing a dramatic decline in popularity in China due to the anti-corruption crackdown and bans on owning large dogs. Previously given as gifts to officials, the dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in hotpots. The breed's rapid urbanization and cross-breeding have also contributed to a glut of low-quality dogs.

The survey of 600 Parisian women found that every woman reported experiencing sexual harassment on the city's public transport, with half of them first harassed before age 18. Harassment ranged from verbal insults to sexual assault, often unreported and "invisible." Sixty percent of women fear attacks on public transport compared to 30% of men, limiting their freedom and forcing them to alter daily routines. The findings led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains, emphasizing the need for education and awareness among both victims and perpetrators.

A competition called #everydayfix by Leeds-based Direct Line asked design groups to create products for common everyday emergencies, such as forgetting to lock the door, losing keys, running out of phone battery, and more. Three prototypes were selected: the Forget Me Lock, a device that indicates whether the front door is locked; Nipper, a small mobile phone charger powered by household batteries; and Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure a good night's sleep. Participants can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winning product will be developed and funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

Vera Baird, the Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner, faces a Ministry of Justice investigation for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity she directs, Victims First Northumbria, alongside Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics accuse the pair of creating a conflict of interest and describe the charity's selection as inappropriate. The controversy stems from a Home Secretary rule allowing PCCs to commission victim services, with Baird previously boasting about securing the funds.

Three people were sentenced for assaulting a 53-year-old man, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive symbols. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, the ringleader, received a 20-year sentence. Sandra Ng, 19, Campbell's girlfriend, was sentenced to 23 months. Another defendant, David Harrison, 28, is awaiting sentencing. The assault occurred in May 2014 in Campbell's mother's basement in Mayfair, Philadelphia, after Campbell believed the victim, Greg Valecce, had hurt his cat and stolen items. Valecce, an unemployed drug addict, suffered severe injuries and escaped on April 1.

Manchester United has made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, aiming to sign the 21-year-old winger. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also attracting interest from other top European clubs.
